justification: The article states that "Set-shifting tasks such as the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)… measure the ability to transition between cognitive-attentional sets," identifying WCST as an instrument for assessing flexibility.
In the same sentence, the authors list "the CANTAB intradimensional/extradimensional test" among tasks that measure cognitive-attentional set-shifting, a core aspect of cognitive flexibility.

The passage notes that the "Dimensional Change Card Sort task (DCCS)" is one of the set-shifting tasks used to measure transitions between cognitive-attentional sets, linking this task to the construct.

The introduction explains that "Common paradigms encompass task-switching…" and earlier defines flexibility as the ability to switch task sets, implying that task-switching paradigms operationalise cognitive flexibility.

The authors describe reversal learning as requiring participants "to adapt responding following the reversal of previously learnt reward-related contingencies," presenting it as another behavioural paradigm for measuring flexibility.

The paper introduces a novel "'change your mind' task" and states "we propose that the ability to change one's responses constitutes a form of mental flexibility," indicating the task is intended to measure this specific flexibility construct.
